bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. BARLETTA:H.R. 6595.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, section 8 of the United States Constitution(clauses 12, 13, 14, 16, and 18), which grants Congress thepower to raise and support an Army; to provide and maintain aNavy; to make rules for the government and regulation of theland and naval forces; to provide for organizing, arming, anddisciplining the militia; and to make all laws necessary andproper for carrying out the foregoing powers.[Page H6429]

item.title: Joint Military Heritage Preservation Act of 2012

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Armed Services.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Armed Services.

summary.text: Joint Military Heritage Preservation Act of 2012 - Directs the Secretary of Defense (DOD) to submit to the congressional defense committees an assessment of the feasibility and advisability of establishing a joint Army-Navy storage and preservation facility at the United States Army Heritage and Education Center, Carlisle, Pennsylvania, including for purposes of the storage and preservation of materials under the responsibility of the Naval History and Heritage Command.

bill.title: Joint Military Heritage Preservation Act of 2012

item.title: Joint Military Heritage Preservation Act of 2012
Joint Military Heritage Preservation Act of 2012
To require a report on the establishment of a joint Army-Navy storage and preservation facility at the United States Army Heritage and Education Center, Carlisle, Pennsylvania.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Armed Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
